content: Of a rather long list of foreign policy issues requiring close attention, none seems more urgent than the United States' relation to Russia. Why this should be the case a decade and a half after the end of the Cold War is, in itself, something of a mystery. Yet, that is exactly what has happened. The mystery is this: what forces are at work to demonize Russia, to isolate and alienate it from the West, and to continue to treat it as an enemy? more

title: Letter to Democrats on U.S.-Russia Relationship

content: A common misconception among Americans is that the fall of the Soviet Union meant that the government of Russia and her client states (many of the former USSR) suddenly became willing to follow and support US foreign policy, democratic ideals, adopt a republican form of government and generally become 'just like us' in thought, word and deed. Nothing could be further from the truth. To expect the CIS to immediately forget any geographical, military or political realities is to forget several centuries of history, both of the Soviet Union and the Russian Empire. Without this history, actions such as the brutal war in Chechnya, their continued opposition to NATO expansion and anti-missile technology, thier support of Serbia, involvement in Central Asia and the occupation of Ossetia and aggression towards the independent Georgia are confusing and bewildering. Unless you realise one thing: Russia will ALWAYS act in the interests of Russia, whether it be strategic (retaining a Black Sea Fleet), internal political control(criminalization of criticism of the Great Patriotic War), or control of resources within its sphere of influence (opposition of Caspian Oil pipelines to the West). Any other expectation for thier political leaders is foolish in the extreme. As is hoping they will change. As I learned in OCS; "Hope is never a good plan." The only reason US-Russian relations have cooled is due to the cold realization of the above situation that began to creep into the minds of the State Department ever since the Balkan crisis of the early 90s and the fiasco of Kosovo (where the Russians supported Serbian aggression in each and every instance). It was confirmed in Chechnya, Central Asia, and now Ossetia. There has been growing doubt about Russian intentions, motivations and alignment with the West. This doubt is due to overt and covert policies, which coincidentally dovetail quite nicely with the strategic plans of the Russian Empire and the former Soviet Union from Peter the Great to Breznev. It's called "Realpolitik" and the Russians have always followed its tenets. To deal with them on any other basis is to akin to playing chess without your queen. Sullivan013

content: Third, there is the matter of oil. The Russians have it and we need it. During the first Clinton term, I urged our government to negotiate long-term oil purchase agreements with the Russians to help reduce our dependence on dangerously unstable Persian Gulf sources. It is not too late to pursue that idea. The Russians need massive Western investment in oil production facilities and the United States and its European allies need predictable oil supplies. High level diplomatic and commercial engagement with the Russians can prevent destructive Russian tendencies to nationalize their oil production facilities. There is no reason that arrangements such as we have had with the Saudis for decades cannot be replicated in Russia. But this will only occur in the context of stable, friendly relations between our two nations. Skytail, here is the main problem. That's just not going to happen. And this does not need to happen. No private industry should control oil in Russia. Something similar happened in Russia before during 90s, and results were disastrous. In all honesty, West needs Russia, more than Russia needs West. I always thought Russia should seek partership in the East, and exactly China. Given that China has the industrial base and Russia and China both have technology, and what they do not have, could be bought from the West in global economy with no problem. If Russia indeed will do what best for Russia, they turn for parternership to East, and they will establish independent food production, like they tried to do for years. They also need to modernize their military. It's funny, that's the West only remembers that Russia is a "western country" when they want something. In all other cases, Russia is a home to "savage mix of various hords". As far as who is trying to demonize Russia, that's our friends in London. That's they are century old technique. They've done with France, they've done it with Germany, now they try todo it with US. If the war was to break out between Russia and US, who'd you think would bear the most of weight on the allies side?
